intro: Amsinckia vernicosa var. furcata, commonly known as the branched leaf globemallow, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the Malvaceae family, which includes mallows and hibiscus. The plant is characterized by its hairy, lobed leaves and showy, yellow flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. It thrives in well-drained soils and full sun, often found in dry, open habitats such as grasslands and rocky slopes. Its unique morphology and ecological adaptations make it an interesting subject for botanical study.
